characters: WHAT DO YOU THINK YOU'RE DOING
IN THE WATER, NEAR THE CLIFFS
BLASTS OFF INTO THE NIGHT SKY
MEMORABILIA, THE WINDS HOWL GROWS LOUDER.
AT THE FAR END OF THE JUNKYARD
AS THE STORM RAGES, HOGARTH EXPLORES HIS ROOM BY FLASHLIG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FIRST MATE yells into the radio, their only hope:

dialogues.speaker: FIRST MATE
dialogues.text: Mayday! Mayday! This is fishing ship "Annabelle"! We're floundering and taking on water! Mayday! Mayday! An enormous WAVE smashes against the bow of the ship, throwing everyone in the cabin off balance. A glass shatters. The Captain enters, the two lock eyes: it looks bad.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: What's our position?

dialogues.speaker: SAILOR
dialogues.text: (grim) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: If you don't know where we are then you don't know where we're going!! You could be running us right into the rocks!! Then: a VOICE breaks through the static on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coast Guard Portland Station to Annabelle: Do you read me? As the mate starts to answer, lightning STRIKES the huge mast. It CRASHES through the pilothouse window, SMASHING radio. Glass, radio parts FLY. The Captain's shoulders slump: now they're done for.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DECK
dialogues.text: The Captain comes out on deck: his men stare at him, eyes full of fear, desperation. Then, impossibly... the WINDS TRAIL OFF. In seconds, the sea flattens into a sheet of glass. All is DEAD CALM. It's eerie. Ropes CREAK. The men ERUPT in celebration, CHEERING, hugging each othe it's over! The angry Captain YELLS:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: It's not over, you idiots! It's just the eye of the storm! The men look around: far off on the horizon, the raging storm still surrounds the ship... but overhead, stars appear. It's eerie, strange.

dialogues.speaker: FISHERMAN
dialogues.text: Look! Overhead, a new, brilliant star appears... and it's quick growing larger. The blazing light speeds toward the startled sailors, impossibly fast, intensely bright, blinding, all goes white... KAWHOOSH! The light CRASHES into the sea. Water flies, th sea BOILS, CHURNING, ROARING, the water green-lit from below. Great clouds of steam BILLOW and HISS. Then, without warning, the raging storm ROARS back with a vengeance, a huge wave SLAMS into the ship. Again the fishermen fight for their lives. But then a dim light appears, far off in the rain: a bare visible beam sweeps back and forth in the storm.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: The lighthouse! Head for it! The desperate men struggle to steer their limping ship toward the light. Then, CLANG! The ship shudders, stops instantly: the ship has SLAMMED into... a wall! A solid wall, a wall made of... iron?  3. The sailors freeze, speechless: they look up the wall, up up... flashes of lightning illuminate: a face! Twin beams of light comes from what look to be... eyes, in an enormo face. A giant?! Made of metal! THUNDER BOOMS. The impossible face seems to turn downward... and looks at the men. The men quake. A HUGE WAVE CRASHES over the ship and throws the men overboard, into the sea. The ship begins sinking fast.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WATER, NEAR THE CLIFFS
dialogues.text: Men surface, cling to ship debris. Two men in a lifeboat pull their comrades from the chill waters. A wave WASHES over rocks, leaves behind a limp fisherman, clinging to the rocks. Barely alive, whipped by wind and rain, he sees lightning-brief glimpses of the giant thing it moves off in the HOWLING storm and dissapears. The VIEW MOVES up, up the rocky cliff to the lighthouse perched atop the cliff. The brilliant beam tries in vain penetrate the RAGING storm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push through the storm towards an upstairs window, and into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashlight beam illustrates the STORM SMASHING against window.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORABILIA, THE WINDS HOWL GROWS LOUDER.
dialogues.text: GLASS SHATTERS and a cold wind whips into the room.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hogarth....?!! The door flies open and Hogarth's mother ANNIE is there. Late twenties, attractive.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Are you alright, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Mom, I'm okay... Annie turns to the shattered window pane, then pushes Hogarth's bookshelf in front of it to block the wind. Hogarth stares at his monther. She looks spooked. HOGARTH (CONT’D) ++. are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I hate when the power goes out. But... yes, I'm fine. Outside, the wind howls.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Wanna stay up with me for a while? (coaxing) I could tell you a story... Annie smiles, touched.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: A story, huh? What have you got for me this time?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Well, it's a story about... Hogarth scans the toys and souvenirs on his bedside table With a sudden flash of inspiration, he grabs a baseball card. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Mickey Mantle. He had a magic bat, Mom. Everybody says so. As Annie watches Hogarth with motherly adoration, Hogarth picks up a plastic dinosaur. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Anyway, this is the story of Mickey's adventures with the stegosaurus. It's got action and romance. And the best part is, it's all true. Annie laughs and touches a fingertip on Hogarth's forehea

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: You've got a lot going on in there, don't you, Hogarth? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wistfully) Just like your father... For a moment Hogarth beams. He looks over at a framed pho that sits on his nightstand, that shows a handsome man dressed in an army uniform. And as he stares at the photo a sad, pensive look comes over Hogarth's face. Annie sees it.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I can't wait 'til he comes back.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (gently) We've been through this before, honey...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: They found his plane, mom. They didn't find him. He's gonna come back. Annie sees the resolute look in her son's eyes and decide to change tack.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: So what could he do with that magic bat of his?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: h (lost in thought) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Mickey Mantle. Could he cast spells with it, like a magician?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Oh... (brightening) Yeah. Yeah that's exactly what he could do. And that's why he was known as the Wizard of Sherwood Forest.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (amused) Sherwood Forest, huh?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Right. And then one day, this Stegosaurus shows up. And he says--— (deep voice) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Who thinks he is mightier than me, the mighty thunder lizard?"

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: And this is all true, now?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Every word, Mom -- I wouldn't make this up. So Mickey says, "I'm the two time American League batting champ. I was MVP of the All-Star game three times running. I go anywhere I please in this forest..." We DRIFT BACK from mother and son, hunkered down in a poo of warm flashlight, surrounded by darkness...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has risen on a beautiful Maine morning. The camera starts HIGH in a tall tree, where a bird is repairing its storm-damaged nest, and pans down from this literal bird's-eye view to the streets of Rockwell, where stoic New Englanders are doing repairs of their own. Down the middle of the street comes Hogarth, on a bike. I the wire bike-basket in front of him is a shoebox with ho punched in the lid. A couple of LOCALS are clearing a felled tree. We hear th conversation as they drift across the screen in Hogarth's travelling POV.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST LOCAL
dialogues.text: Strangest storm I ever seen. Swept away my best iron wheelbarrow. But left the handles behind... Now Hogarth passes a pair of WOMEN who gossip as they rak up leaves and branches.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST WOMAN
dialogues.text: My husband spoke to one of those fishermen this morning. Fellow wouldn't talk about the shipwreck at all. Said we'd all think he was mad.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND WOMAN
dialogues.text: Now what do you think he meant by that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure I don't know. (lowers her voice) But it wouldn't surprise me if the communists are involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Chat ~n-¥ Chew" diner sits near the docks and the to square: the center of all social life in the village. Hogarth arrives, at last, and parks his bike. He takes th shoebox out of his bike basket, opens it a little and spe to whatever is inside.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Remember -- be charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The diner is packed. EVERYBODY is here--FARMERS, FISHERME - all swapping storm-stories. It's LOUD. And there's no empty table, no place to sit. Hogarth enters and looks around. He spots Annie, now dressed as a waitress and serving coffee from behind the counter. Hogarth puts on a big smile and waves at her.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hey, Mom! You won't believe our good luck! Look what I found... He makes his way through the coffee shop to the counter. he passes by, various local ladies -- THE BUSYBODIES -- l up from their breakfasts, mouths downcast and eyes half- lidded -- ever ready to cast judgement, should the precio opportunity arise. Hogarth arrives at the counter opens the shoebox for Anni A baby squirrel pokes its head out. Annie rolls her eyes. HOGARTH (CONT’D) His tree musta gotten knocked down in the storm! Can I keep him?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth, we've been through this. No pets...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: But he's not a pet, Mom. He's a friend. You're always saying I should have more friends come over, right? Well now I've got one. (selling it) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta admit I'm making sense here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth, if there's one thing we've learned from your many pets, it's that claws and furniture do not mix.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I know but--

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: No "buts." We have got to rent a room this year if we're going to make ends meet... Nearby a Busybody perks up her ears, elbows her neighbor, and raises her eyebrows significantly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .»..and no one wants to live ina place with shredded upholstery.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: You'll never know he's there. I'll keep him in a cage--

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: -until you feel sorry for him and "set him free" in the house. Remember the raccoon, Hogarth? God, I remember the raccoon...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Please, mom. At least look at him...

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (softening) Alright, where is this guy...? Hogarth grins and reaches down for his box... then notice there's nothing inside it. The squirrel has escaped. Hogarth looks back at Annie, hiding his desperation.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I... will go get him... okay? Hogarth turns, his eyes darting around frantically. Final he spies a FURRY TAIL disappearing under a four-person ta with a single occupant, hidden behind a newspaper.  HOGARTH (CONT’D) Excuse me...? Excuse me... No response. Behind the paper, smoke rises. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Sir? Still no response. Hogarth is getting exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir...? Sir? Sir! EXCUSE ME, S-- Hogarth STOPS with sudden realization. He slowly pushes d the top of the paper, revealing that the person he's talk to ... ...is ASLEEP. A lit cigarette with an impossibly long ash dangles precariously from his lips. This is DEAN McCOPPEN sporting sunglasses, handsome in a rumpled sort of way. Unshaved, uncombed, unusual. A beatnik. Here. Hogarth's heard of them, but this is the first one he's seen up clo The beatnik's head lolls... ...and his cigarette drops in his lap. He WAKES.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I was snoring, right? Sorry, man. I'm just not a morning person...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Please don't move, sir. My pet's under your table--don't look--if you make a scene my mom won't let me keep him.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Don't worry sonny, I'm cool as a cucumb- (SHRIEK OF PAIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He LEAPS up, HOLLERING, SLAPPING at his smoking pants.

dialogues.speaker: ON ANNIE
dialogues.text: as she turns to watch the COMMOTION from across the room. The busybodies are all abuzz. Who is the weird guy with Hogarth?  10.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME DEAN
dialogues.text: as Dean finally gets under control. He looks around. The whole joint is staring at him. He picks up his cigarette butt and holds it as he addresses the other diners.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Had a little cigarette mishap. It's under control. Show's over. Cool yourselves and resume breakfasting, people. (sitting, to Hogarth) What kind of pet, kid?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: A squirrel. Don't worry, he's friendly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Is my son bothering you, sir? Dean stares at Annie, smiling strangely.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Yes. No. Call me Dean. As Dean and Annie size each other up, the three Busybodie whisper cattily back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST BUSYBODY
dialogues.text: Oh! I don't know why they let such people in here.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BUSYBODY
dialogues.text: She ought to ignore him.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD BUSYBODY
dialogues.text: You forget how single she is, dear. The busybodies exchange smug, catty grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is very low, as an official-looking car pulls and comes to a stop in front of us, its front grille fill the screen. The words "U.S. GOVERNMENT" are printed boldl across the top of the license plate.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAMERA PULLS OUT
dialogues.text: And the driver's side car door opens. A well dressed man his mid-thirties, KENT MANSLEY, steps out, puffs on his p and surveys his surroundings with a steely-eyed, square- jawed gaze.  11. Now a troubled look comes over him, as he notices the US COVERNMENT decal on his car door is peeling off. He press it flat -- it curls up again. He presses it flat -- it curls. He licks his fingers, rubs it on the decal and presses it hard -- and it holds. Kent's look of confidenc returns. He slams the car door with authority; one side o the license plate unhinges and hangs at an angle. Kent si with defeat, and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie speaks gently to Hogarth.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth. I thought you were getting your pet, honey.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I will, mom. After I finish talking to-

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (still smiling strangely) Dean.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: --Dean. Annie shrugs, exits. Hogarth looks at Dean curiously.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I found your pet.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (maintaining clenched smile) Up my leg, man. Squirrel's in my pants, Hogarth. I'm tryin' not to wig out here.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Don't wig out.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (quietly, skin crawling) Okay... he's heading north. (finally) I'm sorry, kid... Dean stands spastically, again addresses the room.  DEAN (CONT’D) I'd like to apologize to everyone in advance for this. He unzips his fly and out pops the squirrel. There is a collective GASP, then a series of shrieks as the squirrel scampers around the diner. Dean zips up and sits back dow DEAN (CONT’D) Check, please. Annie GLARES at a sheepish Hogarth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent now holds a clipboard, taking notes as he talks to a OLD FARMER. Nearby stands a tractor with a bite taken out of it.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: And did you see any strange lights in the sky last night? Any saucer- shaped flying objects?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Were any of your live stock disoriented this morning? Did your cows appear anxious or depressed?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: No... (getting suspicious) ...who did you say you worked for again? Kent puffs himself up a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Frankly I'm not at liberty to reveal the particulars of the agency I work for. He leans in confidentially. KENT (CONT’D) But between you and me, I represent the United States Government. U.P.D. The Unexplained Phenomena Department. The Farmer also leans in confidentially.  13.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, uh... no. Our scope is less limited than the CIA. Unexplained Phenomena, my friend -- that could be anything.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: You work out of the Pentagon, then?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Well, sure, we work near the Pentagon, yes. You know Radcliffe Street?

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Well, trust me, it's pretty much Pentagon adjacent. And all that that implies.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: So, what do you think got to my tractor? Something the commies built? Some kind of monster? Something from outer space? Kent thinks for a moment, then deflates a little.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: No, it's probably something else. (sighs wearily) It's always something else. He makes a note on his clipboard. In the background, Dean approaches and hooks up the tractor to his tow truck and hauls it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth comes home. The phone RINGS, and he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (automatic, without inflection) Hello this is Hogarth Hughes speaking who's calling please.  14.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth, honey... I'm really sorry, but I need to work late tonight. There's some cold chicken in the ice box. You can have that and some carrots--

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I'm already on it, Mom. He pulls a box of twinkies from a cupboard.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Good. I'll make it up to you, okay?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: I love you honey. And Hogarth? No scary movies, no late snacks, in bed by eight. Got it?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Got it. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE CLOCK
dialogues.text: is at 8:47... lit up by the ghostly flickering light of t television. We hear CREEPY MUSIC filtered through the tin t.v. speaker. CAMERA DRIFTS to:

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: ... taking a TWINKIE from a package. He SHAKES up a can of whipped cream, jams it into the flat side of the Twinkie, INFLATING it with additional whipped cream. He CRAMS the twinkie in into his mouth, never taking his eyes off the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit by the light of a black and white TV, Hogarth has mov furniture and piled up cushions, making a TV watching fortress. There's a NOISE OUTSIDE. Hogarth jumps. Listens. Must have been the TV.  15. ON the TV, a scientist and his assistant are involved in some kind of drama that includes a murderous brain. ANOTHER NOISE OUTSIDE, louder this time. Hogarth freezes: that didn't come from the TV.... ROAR! The TV screen goes white with DEAFENING STATIC.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: No! Not now! He SMACKS the TV: no effect. He cranks the big channel knob: THUNK-THUNK-THUNK. All channels are static. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Stupid antenna...! Hogarth stares at the screen, gathers his nerve. He hefts his flashlight and warily heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth peers out. All quiet, just a WHISPER of wind. He crawls out onto the roof, his flashlight beam follows the flat TV wire up the roof toward its peak... and stops: th antenna is gone, literally torn off the roof!

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Gone. Now Hogarth pauses and cocks his head, listening. In the distance he hears a heavy "BOOM." And then another. He peers off into the woods. In the distance he seems to see something moving, just above the level of the trees. Something enormous. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Whoa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth hurriedly equips himself: he tapes a flashlight o a toy BB-gun; puts on a football helmet. Finally, he look in the mirror and salutes himself.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hogarth Hughes. Ready for action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth hurries out, runs up to the first massive depress in the grass. Hogarth places his tiny foot beside the car size depression, and very nearly loses his nerve.  16. He takes a deep breath and hurries into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark night, fog drifts through trees. Spooky. At the forest's edge, Hogarth looks up, sees broken branches whe something entered the woods... something big. Hogarth darts from bush to bush, follows the trail. TIME DISSOLVE: Hogarth creeps on, the forest is now dense More and more, the tree-damage begins to take shape, a ta tunnel formed by broken limbs, until... Hogarth GASPS: the tunnel forms a perfect outline of a HU man-shaped THING. He SHIVERS, considers turning back... b he can't. He creeps on. Hogarth hears a deep RHYTMIC HUMMING that VIBRATES the ground. It sounds strange... alien. He creeps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HUMMING is LOUD. Hogarth slowly parts bushes to see.. a power station: "DANGER - HIGH VOLTAGE". Tall power line towers march through the woods. SPARKS SNAP. THUMP! A giant metal foot SLAMS into the ground right in front of Hogarth, he YELPS. THUMP! THUMP! THUMP! ‘Two huge feet become two huge legs. Hogarth looks up, up... A GIANT. Made of metal! Forty feet tall, maybe fifty! Hogarth can't believe his eyes... The giant stares at the metal towers, makes a METALLIC GR that sounds... hungry. It reaches out and SNAPS off a thi piece of metal, pops it in his mouth, CHEWS NOISILY, and SWALLOWS. BURP. Mmmm good!

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Wow... it eats metal. Cool. Hogarth sits, hidden in the bushes, and watches, fascinat as the giant "grazes" the metal towers. SPARKS fly from n loose flailing powerlines. The giant's eaten all the tower arms: he TUGS at a solid metal base: it's stuck. So the giant bends down to EAT hi way down the tall metal tower: CHOMP CHOMP CHOMP. Hogarth realizes the giant is CHOMPING toward a mass of thick power cables that HUMM and SPARK.  17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie grabs a flashlight by the door, illuminates the living room... what a mess! And... no Hogarth. KA-ZAPPP! Electricity races up and down the giant's metal it jerks, flies backward, trailing SPARKING POWERLINES th wrap around him as he stumbles into a tangle of more powe lines: KA-ZAP! It panics, flailing, SCREECHING, tries to free itself, gets more entangled. Annie searches through the house by flashlight, for her s becoming more and more frantic.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth...? Hogarth! HOGARTH!! SPARKS SNAP AND FLY as the giant SHRIEKS in agony. A towe totters and falls... smashing into the ground just as Hogarth jumps clear. Electricity arcs up and down the Giant's body. The giant ROARS, an AWFUL METAL SOUND, falls to its knees, eyes SPARKING, SHORTING OUT. Hogarth looks around, desperate: he's got to save him! He sees a panel: "EMERGENCY CUT-OFF SWITCH". Hogarth runs toward it, sparks raining all around him. He grabs the panel... locked. He swings his BB-gun like a club: CRASH! The gun breaks, the panel door pops open. Hogarth grabs t huge switch and throws all his weight against it. CLUNK. The SPARKS slowly die away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dazed giant, looks around, dizzy... he stands, sways, easily SNAPS free of the wires holding him. His eyes focu down (way down) on Hogarth. The boy and the Giant stare a each other for a long time. Now what?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (CALLING) Hogarth! Hogarth turns: down the hill, through the fog, he sees a light floating through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Mom!  18. Hogarth runs down the hill towards the light... then stop turns back toward the giant.... ...but back where the giant stood, seconds before, is now only dangling SPARKLING power lines. He's gone. Hogarth stares: baffled. Annie rushes up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth! She grabs him by his shoulders, tightly, more out of fear than anger.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?!! Don't you know better than to wander off at night, alone?? What if something happened to you???

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, mom... Annie throws her arms around him, hugging him tight, desperately happy to know that her boy is safe.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Don't ever do that to me again, Hogarth. I was so scared, I thought I'd lost you... A long moment passes with Annie just holding him and rocking... then--

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (softly) Mom, you won't believe it. Some- thing ate our t.v. antenna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Hogarth...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: No, I'm serious! And I went out to see what it was--

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (losing patience) Hogarth... please...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: --and it was a Giant metal--  19.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: HOGARTH! Stop it! I'm not in the mood. (gentle, but firm) Come on. Let's go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth sits in silence as Annie starts the ignition. As they drive away, Hogarth can't help but look back over hi shoulder. Backlit by the moon, he can just make out the outline of the Giant, half-hidden by the trees... watchin them go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The North Maine woods, the trees sway, holding their secr deep within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEACHER is quizzing her students. Hogarth is the smallest one in the class. On the chalkboard are written the words "RUSSIA" and "POLAND."

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: And who can name another country that is part of the U.S.S.R.? Hogarth raises his hand. TEACHER (CONT’D) Anyone besides Hogarth? Hogarth lowers his hand. No response from the others. TEACHER (CONT’D) Anyone actually listening to me other than Hogarth? Hogarth, are we going to have to move you up another grade? Or should we move the rest of the class down? Alright, that's it. Everyone in the class except Hogarth can write me a five page essay. Call it "Allies and Enemies of the United States of America." It's due tomorrow. The class groans. A big kid turns around to Hogarth, poin at him, and gives him the "slit throat" sign. Hogarth WIL  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Workers swarm over the towers, repairing the damage. Kent is there, smoking a pipe as he talks to a foreman.

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, sometimes a line'll snap if the weather's bad, sure. But fora whole tower to get twisted up like that? (SCRATCHES HIS HEAD) I tell you, it's got me beat.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: And not a single witness...

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: 'Fraid not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Could this have been caused by a giant metal monster, perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: FOREMAN
dialogues.text: Pardon me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just repeating a yarn I heard from some fishermen... Just then, something catches Kent's eye.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He walks a few steps away, and hunkers down beside a port of the rubble. A trapezoidal piece of wood is sticking ou from beneath it. Kent pulls it out. It's the handle of a B.B. gun. On Kent's look we cut to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Students pour out of Hogarth's classroom, followed at las by Hogarth, who is a full head smaller than any of them. Now Hogarth's face brightens, as a few kids his size pass by. Hogarth hurries to catch up with them.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hey guys! The kids turn to Hogarth without much enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: Hey, Hogarth.  21.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Listen, you're not going to believe what happened to me last night. I went walking into the forest, and I saw this... giant! The kids exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was made out of metal! And it tore apart the power station. For a moment, the kids stare at Hogarth blankly. Finally, one of them speaks.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: You know what I just remembered? I'm suppose to help some people do some stuff way over in some other place right now.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: Oh those people? Yeah, I'm suppose to do that too.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST KID
dialogues.text: Nice seeing you, Hogarth. As the kids walk away, Hogarth hears one of them speak quietly to the other. FIRST KID (CONT’D) Boy, I hope they never skip me a grade.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND KID
dialogues.text: He's gotten really desperate. A determined look comes over Hogarth's face we cut to...

dialogues.speaker: THE WOODS
dialogues.text: Hogarth marches purposefully into the forest with a camer slung over his shoulder, and a sheet of metal in one hand

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hellllllooo! Come ouuut!

dialogues.speaker: DEEPER INTO THE WOODS
dialogues.text: The woods are denser now, with shafts of autumn sun punctuating the darkened light. Hogarth bangs the metal loudly as he walks.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hey, big metal guy!! It's me, the kid who turned off the power for ya!

dialogues.speaker: A CLEARING IN THE FOREST
dialogues.text: Hogarth sets the metal down, then retreats a safe distance...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Metal! Delicious metal! Come and get it! ...and settles in behind a large log. He aims the camera, and waits. And waits. And waits. This is clearly not as exciting as Hogarth expected. He rubs his eyes, yawns, and lays his head on h arm. And the next thing he knows, he's waking up. The afternoo light has given way to the long shadows of early evening. Hogarth looks towards the clearing -- the piece of metal gone. He gasps. He reaches behind him for the camera, as he scans the forest, left and right. Suddenly he pauses. His hand is n finding the camera. He turns and looks for it. It's gone. Above him a flashbulb pops. A moment later, a roll of fil drops from the sky and lands at his feet. Hogarth picks u the film, and swallows hard. He looks up, a long way up, sees the Giant standing over him, its jaw moving, and a crunching sound coming from its mouth. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Aaaaagh! Hogarth runs as fast as his legs will carry him. He cover twenty feet or so, when -- BOOM! An enormous metal foot touches down in front of him. He runs faster, faster, but with a single step, the Giant covers all the distance between them.  23. Suddenly -- WHACK! Hogarth catches a tree limb across the chin, and is sent sprawling to the ground. The Giant loom over him. Hogarth sits up, his eyes wide with fear, and shouts at the fifty-foot metal monster. HOGARTH (CONT’D) What do you want from me?!! The Giant sits down with a thud. Then he reaches toward Hogarth with a closed fist, turns it palm-upward and open his fingers. There, in his hand, is the four-foot metal handle with "EMERGENCY SHUT-OFF" printed along its length HOGARTH (CONT’D) The shut-off switch... Hogarth looks from the handle to the Giant, in awe. HOGARTH (CONT’D) You saw me save you. As boy and Giant stare into each other's eyes, we cut to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the BUSYBODIES sit around sipping coffee and gossiping.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST BUSYBODY
dialogues.text: Well, in my opinion, it's a woman's obligation to re-marry. If not for herself, than for her child. The Busybodies murmur their assent.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BUSYBODY
dialogues.text: Do you know she left her little boy all alone last night? My son heard he went wandering around all by himself. Near the power plant... At the mention of this word, a figure at a nearby booth lowers his newspaper, and narrows his eyes. It's Kent.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD BUSYBODY
dialogues.text: Tsk-tsk. On the very night those power lines came down? The poor child could have been killed. The Busybodies gasp in shock and disapproval.  24.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST BUSYBODY
dialogues.text: It just goes to prove my point. She ought to provide him with a father figure, if she cares about the boy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She does care about her boy, for your information. Annie enters, tying on an apron. The Busybodies blush and fan themselves nervously.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And she thanks you so much for your concern. (then wearily) More coffee, anyone?

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'd love some. Annie turns. Kent gives her his best smile. Annie pours coffee, we see Kent studying her with a thoughtful, almos sinister look. He glances at her name tag. KENT (CONT’D) Annie. What a very lovely name... Annie smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Giant and Hogarth sit facing each other, each staring the other with curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: So... what are you? The Giant tilts his head curiously but says nothing. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Do you talk? The Giant continues staring, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Talk." You know, words? "Blah- blah- blah," like that. Can you do that -- "Blah-blah-blah?" The Giant opens and closes his mouth in imitation of Hogarth. A series of deep metallic rumblings and clanging come out of his mouth.  25. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Well, you get the concept, anyway. But we need to work on your vocabulary. Let's see. Hogarth looks around, sees a rock, and picks it up. HOGARTH (CONT’D) See this? This is called a rock. "Rock." Try it. "Rooock."

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Kraaan-chunk.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: "Rooock."

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Kroooonk.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (patiently) Rock.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Rog.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Good! See? This is a... rock. A look of dawning understanding comes over the Giant. He looks at the rock in Hogarth's hand.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Rog. He picks up a nearby boulder.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rog?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Yes! The Giant pulls a tree out of the ground.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Rog!

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: No, no. That is a tree. Tree. (POINTS AT ROCK) Rock. (POINTS AT TREE) Treeeee.  26. The Giant's mouth hangs open in awe.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Rog... Treeee-(SOUND OF A TRUCK

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Get it? Everything has a different name. Rock. Tree... The giant's mouth hangs open in awe...

dialogues.speaker: HOURS LATER
dialogues.text: A very tired Hogarth is still seated (uncomfortably now) front of a still awe-struck Giant. The Giant picks up a piece of wood.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (tired) Branch.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Braaannch. The Giant picks up another piece of wood.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's a branch, too.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Braaannch. (picks up a rock) Rog?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Look, we've pretty much covered everything in the forest. And if I don't get home soon, mom's gonna wonder where I am. (gets on his feet) You stay here, okay? I'll come back tomorrow. Hogarth waves to the Giant and EXITS. Now Hogarth hears a BOOM behind him. He turns to see the Giant following him. HOGARTH (CONT’D) And don't follow me, either.  27. The Giant continues following, happily.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said don't. Don't follow me. Stay. Go home. I mean it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fog is settling in, as Hogarth leaves the forest and crosses a set of railroad tracks. He points to the house the bottom of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Look. That's where I live, okay? I'm going there, and you're not, understand? So goodbye. Hey... He turns to see the Giant kneeling curiously beside the railroad tracks. He pokes at them.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: (HUNGRY SOUND)

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute-- Too late. The Giant bites down on the twin strands of railroad track and rips them loose like spaghetti.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT DO YOU THINK YOU'RE DOING
dialogues.text: The Giant freezes, puzzled, long strings of railroad trac dangling from his month.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put them back! Now the Giant looks confused and guilty. DING DING DING! The crossing signal blares, red lights flash. The Giant stares at the pretty lights, entranced. Hogarth GASPS, looks down the tracks. He hears a distant whistle blow: WOO-WOOO.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no... .(HE RUNS TO THE GIANT) Put them back RIGHT NOW!!! The Giant stares, puzzled. Hogarth GROANS, runs to a piec of track sticking up and pushes down on it with all his weight... it doesn't budge.  28.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like this. Help me! The Giant sees Hogarth struggling with the curled tracks, takes one index finger, and helpfully pushes on them: KA- BLAM! They're down.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good! That's it! The Giant grunts, pleased with himself... Hogarth HEARS t train, close now. And then he sees-- the pieces of track don't meet up.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Put them together! Like this! Hogarth pantomimes. The Giant lines up one track-- HOGARTH (CONT’D) Now the other one... hurry! -- then tries to line up the other side, but it's tricky, the two chewed-on rails stubbornly resist lining up. Finally, the giant gets them close. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Good enough! Come on! Hogarth takes off, racing like the wind to get out of the He STOPS, looks back...

dialogues.speaker: THE GIANT
dialogues.text: is still fussing with the tracks, trying to get them perfect.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: No! Come on! The train's coming! The Giant is intent on his puzzle: CLICK. CLICK. Almost. Now we see the headlight of a big freight train coming ou of the fog. The Giant continues to fuss. HOGARTH (CONT’D) The train! The Giant finally SNAPS the track into place. CLICK. He grins. A train whistle SHRIEKS! The startled Giant looks as Hogarth hits the dirt and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent examines the broken branches. Hears the BOOM of the train wreck.

dialogues.speaker: RESUME TRAIN CROSSING
dialogues.text: Steam flies. The EXPLOSION dies away. Hogarth looks up. The Giant is gone. The train, its front end smashed, coas down the track, breaks squealing. Hogarth looks around... Then, THUMP! The Giant's head lands beside him. An arm falls here, a leg there. A hand flies down the hil toward Hogarth's house.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Oh no... Hogarth sees the giant lying around in big pieces. He touches the Giant's hand gently, a look of pain and sadne on his face. HOGARTH (CONT’D) (WHIMPERS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then, behind him, the Giant's head, still attached to its torso, sits up. Hogarth YELPS. The Giant's eyes spark, flash and click on. He looks around, dazed, at his scattered parts. HOGARTH (CONT’D) You're alive! The torso has one leg and most of one arm attached. The other pieces seem to come alive and scamper around as if confused. An antenna rises out of the top of the Giant's head and begins to "signal". All the pieces SNAP to attention. They crawl toward the Giant, who gathers them in his arm and looks at Hogarth, confused. Just then we h voices coming from the fog.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello? Is anyone out there? Are you alright? Hogarth squints into the fog.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: The train Conductor. Oh, we're in trouble now...  30. HOGARTH (CONT’D) (turns to Giant) Okay, look. I've changed my mind. You can follow me home. He hurries off down the hill, with the one-legged Giant hopping along behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth enters the barn, with the hopping Giant behind hi

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: You can stay here for now. The Giant takes a seat and sets his body parts down besid him. The Giant's arm parts dutifully line up, the arm fir He picks it up and jams it into its socket. HOGARTH (CONT’D) And try to keep it quiet okay? My mom's not too big on me having any pets right now. "Shhhh" -- get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train ENGINEER and a CONDUCTOR are examining the trac in the swirling fog.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: Whatever we hit, it was something big. A tractor, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER
dialogues.text: More like a tank, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR
dialogues.text: So where the heck did it go? Out of the fog comes Kent, pipe in hand. He casts a glanc at the Conductor and the Engineer, then turns and looks d the hill towards Hogarth's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie enters from the kitchen, wiping her hands on her apron.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Dinner's been on the table for twenty minutes now. Where have you been all afternoon?  31.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I could tell you, Mom. But I really don't think you'd believe me.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Somehow, I don't doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Giant finishes attaching his leg, and is now all together save for a missing HAND. He looks around the bar for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie and Hogarth sit at the dinner table.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Would you say grace, please? Hogarth folds his hands together, and starts to bow his h when he STOPS: behind Annie, the Giant's hand crawls acro the kitchen floor like a tarantula.

dialogues.speaker: OH MY GOD
dialogues.text: Annie looks up. Hogarth rolls his eyes to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my God, we thank you for the... uh, food that Mom has put in front of us and--

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: Hogarth jumps up. The curious hand-- now standing up on t fingers and reaching for an antique vase-- reacts to Hogarth's tone and shrinks back. Hogarth sees Annie stari at him. Again, he covers --

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -the Devil from doing bad things... and-- (TO HAND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GET OUTTA HERE!...uh, Satan. GO! GO! So that we may live in peace. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Amen. That was... (words fail her) ...really unusual, Hogarth.  32.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (leaps to his feet) Gotta use the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Well... (HE'S ALREADY GONE) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Hogarth runs up to the hand, blocking it from going to th cellar. He takes one of the enormous fingers with both hands, and leads it like a baby elephant to the front doo He opens the door revealing-- --KENT, startled, about to knock. He smiles his most charming smile. Hogarth GASPS, SLAMS the door. He breathe hard, panicking. But when he turns around, the hand is GONE. The doorbell RINGS. Not knowing what to do, Hogarth opens it. Kent's still there, smiling, as before.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Hey there, Scout... Kent Mansley. I work for the government. Your parents home?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: We're eating.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Scout? You seem a little jumpy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Who is it, Hogarth? Annie has entered the living room. Kent REACTS.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Why, hello there! Annie, isn't it? From the diner?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: That's right! Mr. Mansley?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Please. Call me Kent. (wheels turning) So this is your house... (to Hogarth) ...then you must be Hobo!  33.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hogarth.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Hobart.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yes indeed. I'm terribly sorry to bother you at this hour, but I'm looking into a little train accident that happened nearby and-- my goodness! Is there a blue- ribbon pie in the oven, or have I died and gone to Heaven?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (smiles) We've just sat down to dinner, Mr. Mansley. Would you care to join us?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: If it's not too much trouble, I'd be delighted! He flashes her a thousand-dollar smile. As Annie turns he back to lead them into the dining room, Kent's smile fade into a calculating look. Hogarth sees it all, and glares as Kent walks past him. Kent doffs his hat, places it over Hogarth's head as he advances into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Pretend you're a gangster. The hat covers Hogarth's head. He stands there, looking ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth, Annie and Kent are seated at the dinner table. Kent is pouring on the charm to Annie, as Hogarth continu to eye him suspiciously. Kent pats his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Well! It certainly is true what they say; the hospitality in these parts is second to none.  34.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Which parts would those be, sir?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Well, you know, uh... Maine.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I never heard anyone say that about Maine. Have you, Mom?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth...

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Oh, it's alright. He's a bright boy. I like bright boys... He lights his pipe and studies Hogarth closely.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So tell me, Hogarth. What do you think of all the goings-on around here lately? Hogarth plays innocent.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Goings-on?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You know, the power plant being destroyed and all.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Careful, Mr. Mansley... he's got a powerful imagination.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Please. Call me Kent. I like to be on a first-name basis with first- class chefs. Annie smiles. Hogarth rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: If it's alright with everybody, I think I'll be excused now.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: But you haven't answered my question, Hogarth. Kent leans in toward Hogarth menacingly.  35. KENT (CONT’D) The powerplant. (leans closer) The train. (even closer) Surely you must have a theory, Hogarth. A bright boy like you. Surely you must have an inkling --

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (blurting it out) There's a monster out there!

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: What???

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: It's a hideous creature, five stories tall, and if you go out looking for it you won't come back alive! There's a moment of stunned silence. Then...

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You're... kidding.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Of course he's kidding.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I'm a kid. That's what we do. Suddenly, a toilet flushes upstairs. A puzzled expression comes over Hogarth's face, then Annie's, then Kent's.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Do you have a guest?

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: No... Hogarth leaps from his seat and dashes out of the room. Kent raises an eyebrow. Annie looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth yanks open the door, revealing: The giant hand, which crouches on the sink as it unrolls pile of toilet paper into a pile on the floor.  36. Hogarth shuts the door behind him, startling the hand, wh leaps to the floor with a THUD!

dialogues.speaker: DINNER TABLE
dialogues.text: Kent and Annie react to the sound, and stare at the ceili

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth labors as he pulls the giant hand toward the open window. The hand resists mildly, like a distracted child-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie stands outside the door. She knocks.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Hogarth? Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent turns his attention to the sounds coming from upstai He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using his whole body, Hogarth tries to shove the giant ha out the open window.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (GRUNTING SOUNDS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent has joined Annie, and the two of them listen togethe

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (LOUDER GRUNTING)

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: This sort of thing is why it's so important to really chew your food... Annie shoots Kent a disapproving look.  37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a mighty shove, he finally manages to get the hand o the window.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: --rrrrrgggggghhhhh! The hand lands with a terrific crash, Hogarth tumbles to ground, and Annie and Kent burst in through the door to

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL--
dialogues.text: Hogarth... sheepishly standing there in a large PILE of unrolled toilet paper.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Good lord, you've been acting strange lately. Kent looks from Hogarth to the open window. In the darkne outside, he seems to see a shadowy figure moving in the dark. He turns to Annie, and gives her his patented smile

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Do you have a telephone I could use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent, hunkered into a corner in an attempt at privacy, speaks into a telephone in a loud whisper. Kent peers around cautiously, making sure he's not observed.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: --let me put it bluntly, sir. I'm onto something big in Rockwell, Maine.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: (tired) What is it this time, Kent?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: This time -- well, this time it's a giant, that's roaming around the town destroying things.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Well, you be sure to file us a report, and we'll be sure to process it.  38.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Excellent, sir. And in the meantime, I'd like to call in my team.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Your... team?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: My backup, my support squad. Half a dozen men are all I need to start...

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: Kent, I know this will come as a shock to you, but we can't just give a team to anyone who asks.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (puffing himself up) Forgive my saying so, sir, but I'm not just anyone, and I've never asked. Before. Until now. (there is a long silence) Sir?

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: You haven't really found something, have you?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I think I have, sir, yes.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: You think. Do you have proof?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Sir, I've got a feeling about this one, a gut feeling...

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: That's lovely, Kent. But let me try to explain how this works. If you called to tell me you'd found, say, a giant footprint, I might send over an expert to make a plaster cast of it. If you saw an

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: actual giant with your own eyes, I might even send you the team you're asking for. Heck, you go so far as to get me a photograph, I could probably get the U.S. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Army over there to Rockwell, Maine. But you tell me you've got a feeling--

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (temper rising) Alright then, fine. You want evidence? I'll get your evidence...

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: (TIRED) That sounds swell, Kent.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: And when I do, I'm going to want a memo distributed! And I'm going to want that memo carbon copied and -- and re-distributed and -- The Chief hangs up. As Kent stands with the phone receive in his hand, a look of dark determination comes over his face. And then we pan up through the ceiling above Kent, into Hogarth's room. Hogarth also holds a phone receiver, with one hand cupped over the mouthpiece. He looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie says goodbye to Hogarth at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Bye, Honey! Have a good day at school.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (WAVING) Bye, Mom. Hogarth pedals his bike away until he's out of sight of t front house, then zips around the side of the house, ditc his bike and grabs a little red wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth pulls the wagon around, collecting metal. He find some cans, an old car muffler, a fallen street sign, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth enters and finds the Giant sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Ahem...  40. The Giant opens his eyes. He sees the wagon full of metal and looks delighted.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: (HUNGRY SOUND)

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: It wasn't easy to fill this wagon. So try to not to eat it all at once- The Giant picks the wagon up, and dumps its entire conten into his mouth. Hogarth is speechless. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Do you have any idea what it took to find that metal??? I scoured the neighborhood! I had to ditch school! I've never done that before, I-- The Giant picks up the wagon and eats that too. Hogarth sighs and takes a seat. HOGARTH (CONT’D) So... now that we've eaten, how shall we spend the rest of our day? The Giant looks at him, not understanding. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Okay. I'll teach you more words. Hogarth stands up and points at his house. HOGARTH (CONT’D) That is my "home." That's where I come from . My... (points at himself) home... Hogarth points to his house. The Giant looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Right. Now where is... (points at giant) ...your home?  The Giant 41. looks at Hogarth's house, then follows Hogarth's pointing hand, and looks at himself. Then a look of deep sadness comes over his face. His shoulders shrug, and his hands turn palm-upward in a puzzled gesture.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: You mean... you don't know where you came from?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Wow. You poor guy... Now we hear a deep rumbling sound. The Giant looks down a his stomach hungrily. The Giant He points HOGARTH (CONT’D) I know, I know. (thinks for a moment) Okay, I know a place where it's all you can eat. But not until after dark. stares at him, uncomprehending. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Let me put it this way. at through the window at the sun.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Sun."

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: "Suuughn."

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: When the sun goes down... Hogarth mimes the sun arcing down the sky to sunset. The taps on the Giant's iron belly. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Feeding time. Get it?

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: (COMPREHENDING SOUND)

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Good! Hogarth starts to leave, then pauses and turns back to lo at the Giant. HOGARTH (CONT’D) You're smarter than you look, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: (puzzled sound)

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (exiting) Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a time-lapse, we see the sun arc across the sky and se over picturesque Rockwell, Maine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two silhouettes creep into the night -- one small, one enormous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ways off, Hogarth relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Come on. Let's go! Hogarth starts walking. The Giant moves past him- BOOM BO BOOM! -and with a half dozen strides, is almost out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: On the horizon, the giant turns, looks puzzled: now what? HOGARTH (CONT’D) Not that fast! Sheesh! Come back here! BOOM! BOOM! BOOM! In two seconds, the giant stands at Hogarth's side and looks down at him, confused. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Pick me up, OK?  43. The giant does as he's told, lowers his huge hand to the ground. Hogarth climbs up on it. The giant carefully raises up his hand, with Hogarth on it. Hogarth grabs ont a finger, and points toward the northwest. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Okay, now. March! Hogarth hangs on for dear life as the giant quickly accelerates. Hogarth looks down, and GASPS: they're reall moving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent is hunting around the power plant with a flashlight, muttering to himself.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (scornful) "Evidence". I'll get your evidence... He scans the vast expanse of forest with his flashlight, sags hopelessly.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: ...somewhere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth and the Giant are marching along a back road on t hills outside town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a magic carpet ride, as the moon-lit countrysid below sails past his vantage point, fifty feet above the ground. Hogarth points at a church steeple.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Church. Churrrch.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Churrr-(CRUNCH)

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Yes. People pray there. (points at another building) School. Can you say that? Schooool...

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Skooo...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Schooool suuuucks...

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Skoooo saauuugz...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Very good. And that's all you need to know about school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent has wandered some distance from the power plant now. His flashlight beam sweeps across the ground.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing... Just then, he hears a noise behind him. He stops. Wheels around -- and the beam of his flashlight catches-- --a MOOSE. Huge. Enormous antlers. Looking right at him. moose SNORTS. Kent backpedals, stumbles backward into a ditch- KENT (CONT’D) Whooooa! --loudly enough to scare off the moose. He gets up, dusts himself off, shines his flashlight around and discovers w he's standing in is not a ditch at all, but a-- GIANT FOOTPRINT, perfectly preserved in a patch of dried mud. Kent GASPS. The gasp becomes a sound of delight. He begin to laugh... And then a single rain drop falls on head. Kent looks up. Another drop falls. The laughter ceases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth is still riding on the Giant's shoulder. Rain has begun to drizzle down now.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: And that building there is the coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: Kau-(CLANG) shawww...  He raises The Giant 45.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: That's where my mom works. Sometimes she has to stay late, to make extra money ‘cause... well, my Dad's away. You know what a "dad" is? A "father?"

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: "Pa-grrr?"

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's like me... (points at himself) Only bigger. a hand indicating somone taller. HOGARTH (CONT’D) He used to take me to baseball games. This one time, we brought binoculars, and we tried to figure out what pitch the catcher was calling! One year we want to go to every home game! I mean-- we wanted to... stops walking and swivels his enormous head to face Hogarth. For a moment, they stare at each other in silence, with the rain pouring down around them. Then Hogarth bursts out, almost angrily. The Giant The Giant HOGARTH (CONT’D) Aw, what am I even talking to you for? You can't understand a word I'm saying! continues staring. HOGARTH (CONT’D) Can you? speaks --and somewhere within the metal clanging of his voice, there seems to be a note of sympathetic sadness.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: "Fa-grrrr." Hogarth sighs, and pats the Giant on the side of the head

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Well, I guess it's better than talking to myself.  46. The Giant looks pleased by this. They continue on their way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent, soaked to the bone, is sitting on the edge of the Giant footprint, which has become a soggy, nondescript me

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: God hates me... He pulls out his pipe, and tries to light it, but his sog matches won't strike. KENT (CONT’D) Damnation! (shouting heavenward) Can't a guy get a break around here?!! Suddenly the rain lets up. Kent looks surprised. Then pleased. He lights his pipe. Then turns to heaven again. KENT (CONT’D) Thank you. Waaagh! He does a huge double take as he looks up to see the Gian smiling head looming above him. The Giant picks up Kent's metal flashlight, eats it, and in three strides is gone f sight, leaving the terrified and exhilarated Kent behind. UNDER THE GIANT'S CHIN... ...Hogarth PEEKS OUT, breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: That can't be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A metal graveyard, sprawling as far as the eye can see.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is it. The Giant's metal hand sets Hogarth down into frame. HOGARTH (CONT’D) All you can eat. The Giant surveys the metal in all directions: MOANING happily as he spies a huge stack of cars. He selects one, and slowly... carefully... bites into it...  47.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT
dialogues.text: (DELIGHTED SOUND)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He selects another car, picks it up and bites into it like a gourmand tasting a fine chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mmmm... He tastes another.

dialogues.speaker: GIANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ooooooh... --causing the CAR HORN TO BLAST!

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: SHHHH!! Turn it off, turn it OFF!!! The giant looks around nervously, helplessly, beginning t PANIC. He tries shaking it, then sitting on it... but nothing works; the horn is STUCK. Hogarth looks back toward the house--

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FAR END OF THE JUNKYARD
dialogues.text: A light goes on in a little house. Finally, the Giant takes a monster chomp and snaps the ca in half. The horn strangles into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean reaches the door, opens it: a GASPING, out-of-breath Hogarth stands on his doorstep. Dean studies Hogarth for moment. Then breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, I know you. Squirrel boy.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hogarth.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: By night known as Hogarth. Got it. Well, come inside kid. Hell, it's raining out there, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazz is playing on the hi-fi of this distinctly bohemian pad. Dean presses an espresso.  48.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Listen, you're not going to call my mom are you? She doesn't know I'm out. I could get in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Don't worry, kid. It's not my style to report a guy to the authorities. He brings over two espresso cups and hands one to Hogarth DEAN (CONT’D) Espresso for me, Bosco for you. But I thought you'd dig the little cup. Hogarth looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: My name's Dean. I'm a nobody. And you are...?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hogarth. I'm... kind of a nobody, too.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So what brings you all the way up here, Hogarth? You riding some kind of crazy inspiration?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I've been riding something alright... The record finishes, and in the silence: LOUD CRUNCHING NOISES from outside. Dean jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Did you hear that??? He grabs a crowbar, runs to the door; Hogarth jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: No, wait! Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door flies open, Dean leaps out, YELLS:

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Who's out there?! He hears a metallic GASP. He looks up, up, up and sees th gargantuan Giant, tailpipes sticking out of his mouth, frozen, a guilty "caught!" look on its face. Dean YELPS..

dialogues.speaker: DEAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --my god! RUN KID, RUN!!!!

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (rolls his eyes) It's OK...! But the heroic Dean seizes Hogarth and turns to duck insi --which the giant immediately interprets as a threat and- --SLAMS his massive hand in front of the door, blocking i as Hogarth tries to break free of Dean, to explain-- HOGARTH (CONT’D) The giant isn't--let GO! as the giant GRABS DEAN, hoisting him high in the air.

dialogues.speaker: DON'T SQUASH HIM
dialogues.text: The giant STOPS--looks down at Hogarth, puzzled. HOGARTH (CONT’D) ...Squash.... him. Good boy. (beat, heavy sigh, then-) His name is Dean. We like Dean. Dean good. Put him down.

dialogues.speaker: THE GIANT
dialogues.text: Dean. The giant grins at Dean; he sways, shocked, overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Dean, meet a friend of mine. Dean, giant. Giant, Dean. The giant grins, and kind of "waves". Dean stands there, pale, completely overwhelmed. HOGARTH (CONT’D) More coffee...?  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dean stares, stunned, at the huge, impassive giant.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So... where'd he come from?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: He doesn't remember. He's like a little kid...

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Little. (mirthless laugh) Yeah. Huh.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: He needs food. And shelter. Dean stares at Hogarth in expressionless shock. Then slow stands, pours out his coffee, goes inside, locking the do behind him.

dialogues.speaker: 37 MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: The blinds have been pulled. Hogarth stands at the Dean's front door, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: You got plenty of room here! This place is perfect!

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (from inside, muffled) Go away.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I can have him push the door down. You know I can. Pause. The door opens and there's Dean, looking annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Hogarth! I can't hide it here!

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Him. Not it. Him.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Whatever! You don't even know where he came from! Or what the hell he is!  51.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) He's ...my friend. Dean stares at immovable Hogarth. Behind him, dawn breaks

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: (low mutter) Yeah. What am I, am I your friend? Bring some frankenbot with out of state plates over here and make me change my tune... don't like that jazz... God, I'm tired... Dean gives up, stands, worn-out, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: So! He can stay?!

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Tonight. Tomorrow, I don't know... (wanders inside, muttering) ...figure something out.... Dean stumbles toward his home. Hogarth grins, and looks a the now-tired giant, YAWNING.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Let's get you tucked in....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth smiles to himself, as he watches the giant sleep, now covered with a layer of junk, a camouflage-comforter. And then he hears a BEEPING NOISE. Hogarth looks up and sees an ARMY PLANE, flying towards him. The BEEPING gets louder. Hogarth realizes it's coming fro the Giant. Suddenly: WHIR, a panel on the giant's arm slides open. A strange device pops out and starts trackin the plane overhead. Hogarth panics: as the plane comes nearer the BEEPING becomes more insistent, the strange device tracks the pla it looks very retro-advanced and scary. The giant starts MOANING, thrashing in his sleep as if caught in a bad dream. Suddenly he wakes up and ka-CHUK!- the device withdraws. The plane disappears over the trees Hogarth looks at the giant, stunned. The giant, unaware, looks at Hogarth, puzzled.  52.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: It's okay. Go back to sleep. It was just a bad dream. The giant nods, comforted, and drops off into sleep. Hogarth walks away, deeply troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth creeps upstairs to his room, pulls back the cover and is just about to dive in... when Annie enters; spies Hogarth up and dressed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: You're up already? Hogarth tiredly replaces the bedcovers.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: ...just making the bed....

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: That's nice. Come downstairs. I have a surprise for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exhausted Hogarth shuffles downstairs, and into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down sleepily at the breakfast table and then GAS sitting across from him, reading the paper and looking qu at home in a fatherly way is --

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Kent...?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Morning, sport. Sleep well? He feels Kent's knowing eyes boring into him.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Moooooooom! Annie appears, carrying a plate of waffles. She sets a plate down and leans in towards Hogarth, beaming.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Isn't it wonderful, Hogarth? We finally got a border!  53.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (PANICKED) Oh no... Kent looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You know, I meant to wake up bright and early this morning. But from the look of those waffles, I'm still in bed dreaming!

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Mansley-- (Kent wags a finger) -- Kent. Kent and Annie share a meaningful look. Hogarth looks ill

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Uh... I'm not very hungry. He exits. Kent watches him go, then picks up the fork tha Hogarth was holding, and surreptitiously drops it ina little plastic evidence bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth strolls in and takes a seat at the counter next t man reading a newspaper. A bored waitress approaches.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Chocolate malted, please. (she exits) I've never been in here. Mom says the coffee's weak and they put meat extender in the hamburger.

dialogues.speaker: MAN BEHIND NEWSPAPER
dialogues.text: It ain't the diner, sparky. But it's more private. The man lowers the paper to reveal his face. It's Dean. H glances around cautiously to make sure they're not being watched.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So. Your friend's got quite an appetite.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Yeah. When I found him, he was trying to eat the power station.  54.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: So where does he come from?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (shrugs) He doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: You can talk to him???

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Kinda. He can't say a lot of words yet, but he understands things pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I wonder if he had something to do with the meteorite that splashed down here the other day. Then again, maybe he was the meteorite...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: That's what I was thinking! He came from outer space!!

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe. Or maybe he was launched into space from earth.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hey, maybe the commies made him! You know, in one of their secret labs.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Or maybe we built him in one of ours. Our government has secrets, too you know.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: (getting into it) Or maybe he comes from underground, you know? Like, he's this undiscovered species, that evolved from minerals or something, while we were evolving out of monkeys.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Maybe, kid. And then, again, maybe the monkeys evolved from us. Dean laughs and puts his hands behind his head, and strik a philosophical pose.  55.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: I wish we knew why he was here.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Hey, I wish I knew why I was here. Hogarth puts his hands behind his head and strikes a philosophical pose, too. He seems to be enjoying the adul conversation.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I mean if you think about it, nobody really knows where they came from, why they're here, or where they're going. We believe. We hope. But we don't know.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Right, right...

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: And some cats, that scares 'em, you know?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: You're telling me.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: They race around, play the game, chase money, chase power...

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Just so they won't have to wonder what life's all about.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Exactly. (beat, suddenly impressed) Hey... Dean lifts his coffee cup, saluting Hogarth. They sit in silence for a moment, happily contemplating the universe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Kent looks on, an AGENT in a lab coat studies a spoon now dusted with white powder -- under a microscope.  56. After a moment, he looks up, and gestures at the BB-gun, also dusted with powder, which lies on the table nearby. Agent turns to the man in shadow standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: LAB-COAT AGENT
dialogues.text: It's the same fingerprint. A match is struck. We follow it up to the man's pipe, already in his mouth. As the match flares it lights up Kent's face. He smiles diabolically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth contentedly slurps the last of his malted through plastic straw. Dean works on a slab of apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Hey, Dean?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: What is life all about? For you, I mean.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: For me? Well... (shrugs) I guess I'd like to prove there's something pure in me, you know? They say the soul is part angel and part monster. Sometimes I think life is a chance to set the angel free.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: The Giant looks like a monster. But inside he's good. I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: I hope you're right, kid. The world could use an angel that size.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: You won't tell anybody about him, will you?

dialogues.speaker: DEAN
dialogues.text: Nah. He's an outsider. I've gota soft spot for outsiders.  57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth comes riding home on his bike. He parks it at the side of the house, and starts to go inside, then hesitate He holds out a hand, and feels a drop of rain, looks up a the clouds... then takes his bike and wheels it toward th barn instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hogarth opens the barn door, and GASPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent and the labcoat AGENT sit at a small, improvised lab table. Nearby are four OTHER AGENTS in suits and ties; studying maps, monitoring listening equipment, generating artist conceptions of the giant. They look up, aghast.

dialogues.speaker: HOGARTH
dialogues.text: Moooom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent and the agents sit stoically at the breakfast table. Annie stands facing them with folded arms. Hogarth stands nearby, scowling.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: So you work for the government?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: That's right. A long PAUSE...

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: Our government?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Of course. Annie, please, let me explain. Every once in a while things happen to people that just can't be rationalized ina conventional way. The Unexplained Phenomena Department was created to respond to the bizarre, the strange, the--well, unexplainable events that happen every day all across this great land. From the mountains to the prairies, to the oceans--  58.

dialogues.speaker: ANNIE
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Do you actually work in Washington?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Yes indeed. Washington D.C... As Kent begins to wax on about his work, we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Kent strides briskly through the crisp morning air, makin his way through many equally ambitous go-getters on their way to do the nations work. Familiar Washington monuments fill the background.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (V.O., CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...if you're of a mind to be a mover and a shaker, it's the only place to be.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Kent enters an impressive government building. While most the workforce heads up the massive marble stairs, Kent he down the narrow stairs off to the side.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (V.O., CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A place where an individual with pluck and ambition can really get ahead...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Kent walks down the endless row of identical doors, stopp in front of one labeled "UNEXPLAINED PHENOMENA DEPT." Ken unlocks the door and enters a sparse, windowless office n much larger than the desk in the center of it.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (V.O., CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...Safe in the knowledge that the vast resources of the U.S. Government are at ones disposal.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
